Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s words echoing in my mind: “This weekend is important. We all need to be together for the family ceremony. It’s tradition.” I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectation. Our family had always taken pride in honoring our customs, and lately, everyone seemed even more insistent that we not let anything interfere. Just as I was about to leave for my room, my phone buzzed. It was Maya, an acquaintance from my art class. “Hey, I know it’s last minute, but could you help me move some boxes on Saturday? I don’t have anyone else to ask.” I stared at the message, torn. Maya sounded desperate, and I knew how hard it was for her to reach out. I wanted to help, to be the kind of person others could rely on. But the thought of disappointing my family, of breaking a tradition they held so dear, made my stomach twist. I sat there, phone in hand, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could bear to let down.
